free_txt: BP: Updated to new date formats, lower
case. Corrections according last EXFOR rules and Dict.
Added DETECTOR, SAMPLE, METHOD, ERR-ANALYS and
CORRECTION. Digitized data.

bib_record.title: Fast neutron capture and activation cross sections

free_txt: The Argonne Tandem-Dynamitron.
Corrections were applied for the capture of neutrons
scattered elastically or inelastically within the
sample, the efficiencies for the capture and the
neutron detector, scattering of neutrons in air, and
the neutron flux attenuation in the samples. In the
case of some low energy resonance cross section
measurements of Ni, only an average correction was
applied for the capture of scattered neutrons.
The capture gamma-ray detector was a
1300-liter iron tank filled with a liquid
scintillator. The scintillation light was viewed by
twelve AVP 57 multipliers. A 1 mm-thick lithium glass
detector was used as a neutron flux monitor in the
white spectra measurements.
The dominant uncertainty is due to the
extrapolation of the capture gamma-ray energy spectra
to zero pulse height. This uncertainty limits the
accuracy of the present measurements to 7 percent at
best. The statistics and background contribute in
this case appreciably to the uncertainty of the data.
The size of the symbols shows the uncertainty of the
measurement.
The Argonne Tandem-Dynamitron.
The samples were placed in the flight-path 2.5
m from the source. This was sufficient to separate by
time-of-flight the low energy neutron group of the
source reaction up to 2.5 MeV primary neutron energy.
The samples consisted of metallic discs with a
diameter of 8.9 cm. With exception of the Ho sample
which contained 2% Er, all samples were at least
99.5% pure.
The targets consisted of metallic lithium
about 0.5 MeV for white-spectrum measurements.
Fig. 3, page 903.
The targets consisted of metallic lithium
about 0.5 MeV for white-spectrum measurements.

The 238U data were averaged over 4, 10 and 20 keV
intervals, eliminating most of the structure which
exists in both the 238U capture and the Au reference
cross sections.
The targets consisted of metallic lithium
about 0.5 MeV for white-spectrum measurements.
Fig. 1, page 902.
The Ni capture cross section has many very narrow
resonances and hence the widths observed in the
measurements are given by the experimental
resolution. In order to improve the statistics of the
results the data were further averaged with a
resolution of about 3 nsec/m.
The targets consisted of metallic lithium
about 0.5 MeV for white-spectrum measurements.
Fig. 2, page 902.
The targets consisted of metallic lithium
with thicknesses between 0.04 and 0.1 MeV for the
production of "monoenergetic" neutrons.
